intro: Gilia cana subsp. bernardina, commonly known as the Bernard's gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a herbaceous annual or biennial species belonging to the evening primrose family, Onagraceae. The plant features showy, tubular flowers that are typically pink to purple in color, with five petals and prominent stamens. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in disturbed habitats such as roadsides and dry meadows. Its botanical characteristics make it a distinctive and ecologically important species in its native range.
